Wish it could look like Rtv.. but still nice.
@ks: It is awesome! Almost better than the real thing..
@ks: It was? I have been using it for awhile and it has been solid.
@ks: Well, most people on Zeronet are looking for anonymity and Keybase is kinda the opposite....  or people might already have it ;)
http://vector.im looks promising..

@Andrewm: It is almost ready. You can try it out on the development branch (http://vector.im/develop). Just enable it in the settings. My reasoning though was that it is really portable. You could have it in Weechat if you'd want.
@ks: Sorry, my bad... I was using the static 'rtv' package and not the git.
@ks: Yeah, gotta love git packages.. so simple to maintain too. I just edited the pkgbuild and are now on 1.11.0 ;)

What software? Desktops generally has very great support for Linux... but this is a ROG so would not swear on it. Different distributions of Linux can differ in how good it is supported. Generally a later kernel is better as it is there you find most of the drivers for Linux.
Doesn't your browser come with one? ;D
Yeah, it would make it look more professional... that I agree with. ;)
Sounds like you should consider getting professional help... or get a hobby where you work with your hands.
Why a RPi2 and not RPi3 or even better a SBC which have gigabit ethernet? I can't see why it wouldn't be able to handle a simple forums site.

If you want power I would consider getting a Odroid-C2 (about double RPi3 and gigabit ethernet) which cost about the same. A Pine64 would also be interesting because of it's price. Which to get probably depends on shipment prices though.
In total agreement with @P2P .. posts shouldn't be deleted permanently but instead auto-archived locally per user.. sharing only the last couple of weeks.
Never heard of it before.. Interesting..

The amount of work you have to put down to get a kernel like the one in Linux, BSD, Illumos or Windows is enormous. Mac is using the BSD and ChromeOS/Android is Linux. No one would be that crazy. Especially when Linux, BSD and Illumos are open source. Today I think Linux is the one with the biggest momentum.. so a new OS would more than likely to be based on it.

So the question is really... why? Why do you wish this? The amount of choice of Linux is staggering already. What do you hope will be accomplished?

@Mynameislegion: Well, there are alternatives like Tizen, Ubuntu Touch and SailfishOS. I personally own a Jolla that runs SailfishOS. The nice thing with it is that is runs on desktop technology like Wayland, systemd and pulseaudio. It works really well and have Android support if it is needed.

@Scrub: This ( http://news.softpedia.com/news/remix-os-has-eula-that-asks-users-to-waive-rights-to-all-user-content-498848.shtml ) makes RemixOS a big no-no... not only this but also that it uses Android.
Lola

This is what is said on keybase download page...

    Note: a community/keybase package exists but is currently command
    line only. If you want the full Keybase experience:

    yaourt -S keybase-bin

Which if I don't recollect wrong is a officially supported package. It is maintained by keybase in other words.

@Musickiller: Yes, it will come with full package... to see where `pacaur -Ql keybase-bin`. Basically what you do is run `run_keybase` and then you should have /keybase/{private,public}. If not you can check with

 `keybase status` if kbfs is running. The app will be found in /opt/keybase/Keybase.
How come?
Ohh.. well, if you buy a new one it will be both cheaper and more powerful (Pine64, Odroid e.t.c..) ;)

Firefox as main and Qutebrowser as a runner up... Have been playing with Vivaldi. Opera will be sold to a Chinese VC and an online game company. Its "vpn service" was hacked in August. Would never touch it. Same with Chrome.

Vivaldi is the true successor of old Opera. The original creator of Opera is behind Vivaldi. Their idea is to have niche (or power user) features. Kinda like in the spirit which made old Mozilla to stand out. So Vivaldi is interesting.. but have not won me over. Firefox still support the features I require and are the lightest of the big ones so have not yet had a reason to abandon them. Palemoon was buggy and I think is not developed anymore.

Qutebrowser is my absolute favorite though.. It's a "keybinding based" browser and while having a little learning curve is very effective. If it get pinned-tab support It is very possible I switch.

@Alex: Vivaldi and Chrome use the same back-end engine.. so site support is the same. Chrome looks awful. I have not seen one good theme. Firefox is without doubt the best looking (after some customization). Have you seen what Vivaldi [can do](https://vivaldi.com/assets/settings-linux.jpg)? Chrome is a joke in comparison... Vivaldi is also evolving and recently got a new theming engine last month.
You did! Cool! It is really nice but do lack some stuff I still require. For someone with fingers on keyboard it is really fast. I am _soooo_ close to switching fulltime myself too.

@Alex: Have you seen for instance FT Deep Dark theme for Firefox? This is just one where it completely alter the looks of Firefox. While themes on Chrome pretty much is just a change of color. In other words.. you can't make Chrome look good. Chrome makes their own standards. Because of this Chrome can be earlier on some stuff and the other implement it when it is a standard. When it comes to CSS filter it seems to be a working W3C draft so far and not a standard yet. Still it is supported in Firefox 48 onwards.
explain?
Wow! Yeah, look at that... but then again.. it is in Sid (Debian Unstable) which is kinda rolling like Arch although less stable from the reports I've heard.

Your little peer searching little parrot was an awesome solution.. Now I get only videos that work. Much better. This hub idea pretty neat too. Would be nice if there later was a searchable index where you can find the hubs you like.
@Alex: Doesn't really change anything..
In case you want to stay out of clearnet... http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Page:zerowikiformat
How much bigger is the Flatpak?
Holy moly... yes, it indeed was. One of the reasons why I hope these bundle solutions don't catch on.
I guess it is nice to have the option.. but I have yet to find a package I have not been able to get working. ;)

Have never used it... what errors do you get? One of the first things I do is ```strace -eopen <application name>``` when troubleshooting.. just to see if something is missing. Usually you will get the answer by either checking the package tracker on aur or by googling the error.
That one is using namecoin-legacy and has been deprecated for namecoin-core. Have you tried the other package in the AUR? The legacy github source is a couple of years old and not updated anymore.
@Dergatt: No, what they do is to point to the namecoin-core repo and in that repo you have the [gui](https://github.com/namecoin/namecoin-core/tree/master/src/qt). ;)
@Dergatt: Not easy? It's available through AUR as with most other stuff. Just search 'namecoin' and install the ```namecoin-core``` ;)

A major deficit is the ability for media to filter out BS today.... BREXIT happened because _leave_ could lie and _remain_ didn't. Trump has pretty much told every lie there is.. Media can't counteract because that will cost them too much revenue. So there aren't really any truth teller out there...

There is not really any difference... Zme+ only give some extra features you wouldn't have else way. There is no fragmentation. The same ecosystem is used. The fork was justified as the features have been requested for Zme but not implemented.
Still using Nok... ehm... Jolla ;)
